Throughput-Optimal Topology Design
for Cross-Silo Federated Learning

Othmane Marfoq

Abstract

Federated learning usually employs a server-client architecture where an orchestrator iteratively aggregates model updates from remote clients and pushes them back a refined model. This approach may be inefficient in cross-silo settings, as close-by data silos with high-speed access links may exchange information faster than with the orchestrator, and the orchestrator may become a communication bottleneck. In this paper we define the problem of topology design for cross-silo federated learning using the theory of max-plus linear systems to compute the system throughput—number of communication rounds per time unit. We also propose practical algorithms that, under the knowledge of measurable network characteristics, find a topology with the largest throughput or with provable throughput guarantees. In realistic Internet networks with 10 Gbps access links at silos, our algorithms speed up training by a factor 9 and 1.5 in comparison to the server-client architecture and to state-of-the-art MATCHA, respectively. Speedups are even larger with slower access links.

1 Introduction

Federated learning (FL) “involves training statistical models over remote devices or siloed data centers, such as mobile phones or hospitals, while keeping data localized” [56] because of privacy concerns or limited communication resources. The definition implicitly distinguishes two different settings [41]: the cross-device scenario including a large number (millions or even more) of unreliable mobile/edge devices with limited computing capabilities and slow Internet connections, and the cross-silo scenario with at most a few hundreds of reliable data silos with powerful computing resources and high-speed access links. While the first FL papers [72, 51] emphasized the cross-device setting, the cross-silo scenario has become popular for distributed training among banks [107], hospitals [19, 93, 69], pharmaceutical labs [67], and manufacturers [74].

In federated learning, clients (e.g., mobile devices or whole organizations) usually train the model through an iterative procedure under the supervision of a central orchestrator, which, for example, decides to launch the training process and coordinates training advances. Often—e.g., in FedAvg [72], SCAFFOLD [45], and FedProx [57]—the orchestrator directly participates to the training, by aggregating clients’ updates, generating a new model, and pushing it back to the clients. Hence, clients only communicate with a potentially far-away (e.g., in another continent) orchestrator and do not exploit communication opportunities with close-by clients. This choice is justified in the cross-device setting, where inter-device communication is unreliable (devices may drop-out from training at any time) and slow (a message needs to traverse two slow access links). But in the cross-silo setting, data silos (e.g., data centers) are almost always available, enjoy high-speed connectivity comparable to the orchestrator’s one, and may exchange information faster with some other silos than with the orchestrator. An orchestrator-centered communication topology is then potentially inefficient, because it ignores fast inter-silo communication opportunities and makes the orchestrator a candidate for congestion. A current trend [104, 18, 100, 95, 7, 49, 53] is then to replace communication with the orchestrator by peer-to-peer communications between individual silos, which perform local partial aggregations of model updates. We also consider this scenario and study how to design the communication topology.

The communication topology has two contrasting effects on training duration. First, a more connected topology leads to faster convergence in terms of iterations or communication rounds, as quantified by classic worst-case convergence bounds in terms of the spectral properties of the topology [75, 24, 89, 90, 103, 40]. Second, a more connected topology increases the duration of a communication round (e.g., it may cause network congestion), motivating the use of degree-bounded topologies where every client sends and receives a small number of messages at each round [5, 61]. Recent experimental and theoretical work suggests that, in practice, the first effect has been over-estimated by classic worst-case convergence bounds. Reference [79] partially explains the phenomenon and overviews theoretical results proving asymptotic topology-independence [61, 81, 5]. [50, Sect. 6.3] extends some of the conclusions in [79] to dynamic topologies and multiple local updates. Experimental evidence on image classification tasks ([79, Fig. 2], [66, Fig 20.], [61, Fig. 3]) and natural language processing tasks ([61, Figs. 13-16]) confirms this finding. Motivated by these observations, this paper focuses on the effect of topology on the duration of communication rounds.

Only a few studies have designed topologies taking into account the duration of a communication round. Under the simplistic assumption that the communication time is proportional to node degree, MATCHA [104] decomposes the set of possible communications into matchings (disjoint pairs of clients) and, at each communication round, randomly selects some matchings and allows their pairs to transmit. MATCHA chooses the matchings’ selection probabilities in order to optimize the algebraic connectivity of the expected topology. Reference [78] studies how to select the degree of a regular topology when the duration of a communication round is determined by stragglers [44, 55]. Apart from these corner cases, “how to design a [decentralized] model averaging policy that achieves the fastest convergence remains an open problem” [41].

Our paper addresses this open problem. It uses the theory of linear systems in the max-plus algebra [6] to design cross-silo FL topologies that minimize the duration of communication rounds, or equivalently maximize the system throughput, i.e., the number of completed rounds per time unit. The theory holds for synchronous systems and has been successfully applied in other fields (e.g., manufacturing [16], communication networks [54], biology [12], railway systems [31], and road networks [25]). Synchronous optimization algorithms are often preferred for federated learning [9], because they enjoy stronger convergence guarantees than their asynchronous counterparts and can be easily combined with cryptographic secure aggregation protocols [8], differential privacy techniques [1], and model and update compression [111, 101, 88, 13].

To the best of our knowledge, this paper is the first work to take explicitly in consideration all delay components contributing to the total training time including computation times, link latencies, transmission times, and queueing delays. It complements the topology design approaches listed above that only account for congestion at access links [104] and straggler effect [78].

The algorithms we propose (Sect. 3) are either optimal or enjoy guaranteed approximation factors. Numerical results in Sect. 4 show significant training speed-up in realistic network settings; the slower the access links, the larger the speedups.

2 Problem Formulation

2.1 Machine Learning Training

We consider a network of N𝑁N siloed data centers who collaboratively train a global machine learning model, solving the following optimization problem:

minimize𝒘∈ℝd​∑i=1Npi​𝔼ξi​[fi​(𝒘,ξi)],𝒘superscriptℝ𝑑minimizesuperscriptsubscript𝑖1𝑁subscript𝑝𝑖subscript𝔼subscript𝜉𝑖delimited-[]subscript𝑓𝑖𝒘subscript𝜉𝑖\underset{{\bm{w}}\in\mathbb{R}^{d}}{\textrm{minimize}}\sum_{i=1}^{N}p_{i}\mathbb{E}_{\xi_{i}}\!\left[f_{i}({\bm{w}},\xi_{i})\right],\;\; (1)

where fi​(𝒘,ξi)subscript𝑓𝑖𝒘subscript𝜉𝑖f_{i}({\bm{w}},\xi_{i}) is the loss of model 𝒘𝒘{\bm{w}} at a sample ξisubscript𝜉𝑖\xi_{i} drawn from data distribution at silo i𝑖i and the coefficient pi>0subscript𝑝𝑖0p_{i}>0 specifies the relative importance of each silo, with two natural settings being pisubscript𝑝𝑖p_{i} equal to 111 or to the size of silo i𝑖i’s local dataset [56]. In the rest of the paper we consider pi=1subscript𝑝𝑖1p_{i}=1, but our analysis is not affected by the choice of pisubscript𝑝𝑖p_{i}.

In order to solve Problem (1) in an FL scenario, silos do not share the local datasets, but periodically transmit model updates, and different distributed algorithms have been proposed [57, 72, 58, 45, 104, 52, 103]. In this paper we consider as archetype the decentralized periodic averaging stochastic gradient descent (DPASGD) [103], where silos are represented as vertices of a communication graph that we call overlay. Each silo i𝑖i maintains a local model 𝒘isubscript𝒘𝑖{\bm{w}}_{i} and performs s𝑠s mini-batch gradient updates before sending its model to a subset of silos 𝒩i−superscriptsubscript𝒩𝑖\mathcal{N}_{i}^{-} (its out-neighbours in the overlay). It then aggregates its model with those received by a (potentially different) set of silos 𝒩i+superscriptsubscript𝒩𝑖\mathcal{N}_{i}^{+} (its in-neighbours). Formally, the algorithm is described by the following equations:

𝒘i​(k+1)subscript𝒘𝑖𝑘1\displaystyle{\bm{w}}_{i}(k+1) ={∑j∈𝒩i+∪{i}𝑨i,j​𝒘j​(k), if ​k≡0(mods+1),𝒘i​(k)−αk​1m​∑h=1m∇fi​(𝒘i​(k),ξi(h)​(k)), otherwise.absentcasessubscript𝑗subscriptsuperscript𝒩𝑖𝑖subscript𝑨𝑖𝑗subscript𝒘𝑗𝑘 if 𝑘annotated0pmod𝑠1subscript𝒘𝑖𝑘subscript𝛼𝑘1𝑚superscriptsubscriptℎ1𝑚∇subscript𝑓𝑖subscript𝒘𝑖𝑘superscriptsubscript𝜉𝑖ℎ𝑘 otherwise\displaystyle=\begin{cases}\sum_{j\in\mathcal{N}^{+}_{i}\cup\{i\}}{\bm{A}}_{i,j}{\bm{w}}_{j}\!\left(k\right),&\mbox{ if }k\equiv 0\pmod{s+1},\\ {\bm{w}}_{i}(k)-\alpha_{k}\frac{1}{m}\sum_{h=1}^{m}\nabla f_{i}\!\left({\bm{w}}_{i}\!\left(k\right),\xi_{i}^{(h)}(k)\right),&\mbox{ otherwise}.\end{cases} (2)

where m𝑚m is the batch size, αk>0subscript𝛼𝑘0\alpha_{k}>0 is a potentially varying learning rate, and 𝑨∈ℝN×N𝑨superscriptℝ𝑁𝑁{\bm{A}}\in\mathbb{R}^{N\times N} is a matrix of non-negative weights, referred to as the consensus matrix. For particular choices of the matrix 𝑨𝑨{\bm{A}} and the number of local updates s𝑠s, DPASGD reduces to other schemes previously proposed [61, 58, 110], including FedAvg [72], where the orchestrator just performs the averaging step (this corresponds to its local loss function fi(.)f_{i}(.) being a constant). Convergence of (2) was proved in [103].

In this paper we study how to design the overlay in order to minimize the training time. While we consider DPASGD, our results are applicable to any synchronous iterative algorithm where each silo alternates a local computation phase and a communication phase during which it needs to receive inputs from a given subset of silos before moving to the next computation phase. This includes the distributed algorithms already cited, as well as push-sum training schemes [5, 91, 87, 76, 23, 98, 109] and in general the black-box optimization procedures as defined in [90].

2.2 Underlay, Connectivity graph, and Overlay

FL silos are connected by a communication infrastructure (e.g., the Internet or some private network), which we call underlay. The underlay can be represented as a directed graph (digraph) 𝒢u=(𝒱∪𝒱′,ℰu)subscript𝒢𝑢𝒱superscript𝒱′subscriptℰ𝑢\mathcal{G}_{u}=(\mathcal{V}\cup\mathcal{V^{\prime}},\mathcal{E}_{u}), where 𝒱𝒱\mathcal{V} denotes the set of silos, 𝒱′superscript𝒱′\mathcal{V}^{\prime} the set of other nodes (e.g., routers) in the network, and ℰusubscriptℰ𝑢\mathcal{E}_{u} the set of communication links. For simplicity, we consider that each silo i∈𝒱𝑖𝒱i\in\mathcal{V} is connected to the rest of the network through a single link (i,i′)𝑖superscript𝑖′(i,i^{\prime}), where i′∈𝒱′superscript𝑖′superscript𝒱′i^{\prime}\in\mathcal{V}^{\prime}, with uplink capacity CUP​(i)subscript𝐶UP𝑖C_{\textrm{UP}}(i) and downlink capacity CDN​(i)subscript𝐶DN𝑖C_{\textrm{DN}}(i). The example in Fig. 1 illustrates the underlay and the other concepts we are going to define.

The connectivity graph 𝒢c=(𝒱,ℰc)subscript𝒢𝑐𝒱subscriptℰ𝑐\mathcal{G}_{c}=(\mathcal{V},\mathcal{E}_{c}) captures the possible direct communications among silos. Often the connectivity graph is fully connected, but specific NAT or firewall configurations may prevent some pairs of silos to communicate. If (i,j)∈ℰc𝑖𝑗subscriptℰ𝑐(i,j)\in\mathcal{E}_{c}, i𝑖i can transmit its updated model to j𝑗j. The message experiences a delay that is the sum of two contributions: 1) an end-to-end delay l​(i,j)𝑙𝑖𝑗l(i,j) accounting for link latencies, and queueing delays long the path, and 2) a term depending on the model size M𝑀M and the available bandwidth111 The available bandwidth of a path is the maximum rate that the path can provide to a flow, taking into account the rest of the traffic [15, 39]; it is then smaller than the minimum link capacity of the path. A​(i,j)𝐴𝑖𝑗A(i,j) of the path. Each pair of silos (i,j)𝑖𝑗(i,j) can use probing packets [39, 84, 38] to measure end-to-end delays and available bandwidths and communicate them to the orchestrator, which then designs the topology. We assume that in the stable cross-silo setting these quantities do not vary or vary slowly, so that the topology is recomputed only occasionally, if at all.

The training algorithm in (2) does not need to use all potential connections. The orchestrator can select a connected subgraph of 𝒢csubscript𝒢𝑐\mathcal{G}_{c}. We call such subgraph overlay and denote it by 𝒢o=(𝒱,ℰo)subscript𝒢𝑜𝒱subscriptℰ𝑜\mathcal{G}_{o}=(\mathcal{V},\mathcal{E}_{o}), where ℰo⊂ℰcsubscriptℰ𝑜subscriptℰ𝑐\mathcal{E}_{o}\subset\mathcal{E}_{c}. Only nodes directly connected in 𝒢osubscript𝒢𝑜\mathcal{G}_{o} will exchange messages. We can associate a delay to each link (i,j)∈ℰo𝑖𝑗subscriptℰ𝑜(i,j)\in\mathcal{E}_{o}, corresponding to the time interval between the beginning of a local computation at node i𝑖i, and the receiving of i𝑖i’s updated model by j𝑗j:

do​(i,j)=s×Tc​(i)+l​(i,j)+MA​(i,j)=s×Tc​(i)+l​(i,j)+Mmin⁡(CUP​(i)|𝒩i−|,CDN​(j)|𝒩j+|,A​(i′,j′)),subscript𝑑𝑜𝑖𝑗𝑠subscript𝑇𝑐𝑖𝑙𝑖𝑗𝑀𝐴𝑖𝑗𝑠subscript𝑇𝑐𝑖𝑙𝑖𝑗𝑀subscript𝐶UP𝑖subscriptsuperscript𝒩𝑖subscript𝐶DN𝑗subscriptsuperscript𝒩𝑗𝐴superscript𝑖′superscript𝑗′d_{o}(i,j)=s\times T_{c}(i)+l(i,j)+\frac{M}{A(i,j)}=s\times T_{c}(i)+l(i,j)+\frac{M}{\min\left(\frac{C_{\textrm{UP}}(i)}{|\mathcal{N}^{-}_{i}|},\frac{C_{\textrm{DN}}(j)}{|\mathcal{N}^{+}_{j}|},A(i^{\prime},j^{\prime})\right)}, (3)

where Tc​(i)subscript𝑇𝑐𝑖T_{c}(i) denotes the time to compute one local update of the model. We also define do​(i,i)=s×Tc​(i)subscript𝑑𝑜𝑖𝑖𝑠subscript𝑇𝑐𝑖d_{o}(i,i)=s\times T_{c}(i). Equation (3) holds under the following assumptions. First, each silo i𝑖i uploads its model in parallel to its out-neighbours in 𝒩i−subscriptsuperscript𝒩𝑖\mathcal{N}^{-}_{i} (with a rate at most CUP​(i)/|𝒩i−|subscript𝐶UP𝑖subscriptsuperscript𝒩𝑖C_{\textrm{UP}}(i)/|\mathcal{N}^{-}_{i}|). Second, downloads at j𝑗j happen in parallel too. While messages from different in-neighbours may not arrive at the same time at j𝑗j’s downlink, their transmissions are likely to partially overlap. Finally, different messages do not interfere significantly in the core network, where they are only a minor component of the total network traffic (A​(i′,j′)𝐴superscript𝑖′superscript𝑗′A(i^{\prime},j^{\prime}) does not depend on 𝒢osubscript𝒢𝑜\mathcal{G}_{o}).

Borrowing the terminology from P2P networks [71] we call a network edge-capacitated if access links delays can be neglected, otherwise we say that it is node-capacitated. While in cross-device FL the network is definitely node-capacitated, in cross-silo FL—the focus of our work—silos may be geo-distributed data centers or branches of a company and then have high-speed connections, so that neglecting access link delays may be an acceptable approximation.

Our model is more general than those considered in related work: [104] considers do​(i,j)=M×|𝒩i−|/CUP​(i)subscript𝑑𝑜𝑖𝑗𝑀subscriptsuperscript𝒩𝑖subscript𝐶UP𝑖d_{o}(i,j)=M\times|\mathcal{N}^{-}_{i}|/C_{\textrm{UP}}(i) and [78] considers do​(i,j)=Tc​(i)subscript𝑑𝑜𝑖𝑗subscript𝑇𝑐𝑖d_{o}(i,j)=T_{c}(i) (but it accounts for random computation times).

2.3 Time per Communication Round (Cycle Time)

Let ti​(k)subscript𝑡𝑖𝑘t_{i}(k) denote the time at which worker i𝑖i starts computing wi​((s+1)​k+1)subscript𝑤𝑖𝑠1𝑘1w_{i}((s+1)k+1) according to (2) with ti​(0)=0subscript𝑡𝑖00t_{i}(0)=0. As i𝑖i needs to wait for the inputs wj​((s+1)​k)subscript𝑤𝑗𝑠1𝑘w_{j}((s+1)k) from its in-neighbours, the following recurrence relation holds

ti​(k+1)=maxj∈𝒩i+∪{i}⁡(tj​(k)+do​(j,i)).subscript𝑡𝑖𝑘1subscript𝑗subscriptsuperscript𝒩𝑖𝑖subscript𝑡𝑗𝑘subscript𝑑𝑜𝑗𝑖t_{i}(k+1)=\max_{j\in\mathcal{N}^{+}_{i}\cup\{i\}}(t_{j}(k)+d_{o}(j,i)). (4)

This set of relations generalizes the concept of a linear system in the max-plus algebra, where the max\max operator replaces the usual sum and the ++ operator replaces the usual product. We refer the reader to [6] for the general theory of such systems and we present here only the key results for our analysis.

We call the time interval between ti​(k)subscript𝑡𝑖𝑘t_{i}(k) and ti​(k+1)subscript𝑡𝑖𝑘1t_{i}(k+1) a cycle. The average cycle time for silo i𝑖i is defined as τi=limk→∞ti​(k)/ksubscript𝜏𝑖subscript→𝑘subscript𝑡𝑖𝑘𝑘\tau_{i}=\lim_{k\to\infty}t_{i}(k)/k. The cycle time 1) does not depend on the specific silo (i.e., τi=τjsubscript𝜏𝑖subscript𝜏𝑗\tau_{i}=\tau_{j}) [6, Sect. 7.3.4], and 2) can be computed directly from the graph 𝒢osubscript𝒢𝑜\mathcal{G}_{o} [6, Thm. 3.23]. In fact:

τ​(𝒢o)=maxγ⁡do​(γ)|γ|,𝜏subscript𝒢𝑜subscript𝛾subscript𝑑𝑜𝛾𝛾\tau(\mathcal{G}_{o})=\max_{\gamma}\frac{d_{o}(\gamma)}{|\gamma|}, (5)

where γ𝛾\gamma is a generic circuit, i.e., a path (i1,…,ip=i1)subscript𝑖1…subscript𝑖𝑝subscript𝑖1(i_{1},\dots,i_{p}=i_{1}) where the initial node and the final node coincide, |γ|=p𝛾𝑝|\gamma|=p is the length of the circuit, and do​(γ)=∑k=1p−1do​(ik,ik+1)subscript𝑑𝑜𝛾superscriptsubscript𝑘1𝑝1subscript𝑑𝑜subscript𝑖𝑘subscript𝑖𝑘1d_{o}(\gamma)=\sum_{k=1}^{p-1}d_{o}(i_{k},i_{k+1}) is the sum of delays on γ𝛾\gamma. A circuit γ𝛾\gamma of 𝒢osubscript𝒢𝑜\mathcal{G}_{o} is called critical if τ​(𝒢o)=do​(γ)/|γ|𝜏subscript𝒢𝑜subscript𝑑𝑜𝛾𝛾\tau(\mathcal{G}_{o})=d_{o}(\gamma)/{|\gamma|}. There exist algorithms with different complexity to compute the cycle time [46, 20].

The cycle time is a key performance metric for the system because the difference |ti​(k)−τ​(𝒢o)×k|subscript𝑡𝑖𝑘𝜏subscript𝒢𝑜𝑘|t_{i}(k)-\tau(\mathcal{G}_{o})\times k| is bounded for all k≥0𝑘0k\geq 0 so that, for large enough k𝑘k, ti​(k)≈τ​(𝒢o)×ksubscript𝑡𝑖𝑘𝜏subscript𝒢𝑜𝑘t_{i}(k)\approx\tau(\mathcal{G}_{o})\times k. In particular, the inverse of the cycle time is the throughput of the system, i.e., the number of communication rounds per time unit. An overlay with minimal cycle time minimizes the time required for a given number of communication rounds. This observation leads to our optimization problem.

2.4 Optimization Problem

Given a connectivity graph 𝒢csubscript𝒢𝑐\mathcal{G}_{c}, we want the overlay 𝒢osubscript𝒢𝑜\mathcal{G}_{o} to be a strong digraph (i.e., a strongly connected directed graph) with minimal cycle time. Formally, we define the following Minimal Cycle Time problem: {problem} Note that the input does not include detailed information about the underlay 𝒢usubscript𝒢𝑢\mathcal{G}_{u}, but only information available or measurable at the silos (see Sect. 2.2). To the best of our knowledge, our paper is the first effort to study Mct. The closest problem considered in the literature is, for a given overlay, to select the largest delays that guarantee a minimum throughput [28, 21].

3 Theoretical Results and Algorithms

In this section we present complexity results for Mct and algorithms to design the optimal topology in different settings. Table 1 lists these algorithms, their time-complexity, and their guarantees. We note that in some cases we adapt known algorithms to solve Mct. All proofs and auxiliary lemmas are in Appendix E.

3.1 Edge-capacitated networks

Remember that we call a network edge-capacitated if access links delays can be neglected, as it is for example the case whenever 1N×min⁡(CUP​(i),CDN​(j))≥A​(i′,j′)1𝑁subscript𝐶UP𝑖subscript𝐶DN𝑗𝐴superscript𝑖′superscript𝑗′\frac{1}{N}\times\min\left(C_{\textrm{UP}}(i),C_{\textrm{DN}}(j)\right)\geq A(i^{\prime},j^{\prime}) for each (i,j)∈ℰc𝑖𝑗subscriptℰ𝑐(i,j)\in\mathcal{E}_{c}. In this setting (3) becomes

do​(i,j)=s×Tc​(i)+l​(i,j)+MA​(i′,j′),subscript𝑑𝑜𝑖𝑗𝑠subscript𝑇𝑐𝑖𝑙𝑖𝑗𝑀𝐴superscript𝑖′superscript𝑗′d_{o}(i,j)=s\times T_{c}(i)+l(i,j)+\frac{M}{A(i^{\prime},j^{\prime})}, (6)

and then the delay between two silos does not depend on the selected overlay 𝒢osubscript𝒢𝑜\mathcal{G}_{o}.

FL algorithms often use an undirected overlay with symmetric communications, i.e., (i,j)∈ℰo⇒(j,i)∈ℰo𝑖𝑗subscriptℰ𝑜⇒𝑗𝑖subscriptℰ𝑜(i,j)\in\mathcal{E}_{o}\Rightarrow(j,i)\in\mathcal{E}_{o}. This is the case of centralized schemes, like FedAvg, but is also common for other consensus-based optimization schemes where the consensus matrix 𝑨𝑨{\bm{A}} is required to be doubly-stochastic [77, 87, 103]—a condition simpler to achieve when 𝒢osubscript𝒢𝑜\mathcal{G}_{o} is undirected.

When building an undirected overlay, we can restrict ourselves to consider trees as solutions of Mct (Lemma E.1). In fact, additional links can only increase the number of circuits and then increase the cycle time (see (5)). Moreover, we can prove that the overlay has simple critical circuits of the form γ=(i,j,i)𝛾𝑖𝑗𝑖\gamma=(i,j,i), for which do​(γ)/|γ|=(do​(i,j)+do​(j,i))/2subscript𝑑𝑜𝛾𝛾subscript𝑑𝑜𝑖𝑗subscript𝑑𝑜𝑗𝑖2d_{o}(\gamma)/|\gamma|=(d_{o}(i,j)+d_{o}(j,i))/2 (Lemma E.2). Intuitively, if we progressively build a tree using the links in 𝒢csubscript𝒢𝑐\mathcal{G}_{c} with the smallest average of delays in the two directions, we obtain the overlay with minimal cycle time. This construction corresponds to finding a minimum weight spanning tree (MST) in an opportune undirected version of 𝒢csubscript𝒢𝑐\mathcal{G}_{c}:

Proposition 3.1.

Consider an undirected weighted graph 𝒢c(u)=(𝒱,ℰc(u))superscriptsubscript𝒢𝑐𝑢𝒱superscriptsubscriptℰ𝑐𝑢\mathcal{G}_{c}^{(u)}=(\mathcal{V},\mathcal{E}_{c}^{(u)}), where (i,j)∈ℰc(u)𝑖𝑗superscriptsubscriptℰ𝑐𝑢(i,j)\in\mathcal{E}_{c}^{(u)} iff (i,j)∈ℰc𝑖𝑗subscriptℰ𝑐(i,j)\in\mathcal{E}_{c} and (j,i)∈ℰc𝑗𝑖subscriptℰ𝑐(j,i)\in\mathcal{E}_{c} and where (i,j)∈ℰc(u)𝑖𝑗superscriptsubscriptℰ𝑐𝑢(i,j)\in\mathcal{E}_{c}^{(u)} has weight dc(u)​(i,j)=(do​(i,j)+do​(j,i))/2superscriptsubscript𝑑𝑐𝑢𝑖𝑗subscript𝑑𝑜𝑖𝑗subscript𝑑𝑜𝑗𝑖2d_{c}^{(u)}(i,j)=(d_{o}(i,j)+d_{o}(j,i))/2. A minimum weight spanning tree of 𝒢c(u)superscriptsubscript𝒢𝑐𝑢\mathcal{G}_{c}^{(u)} is a solution of Mct when 𝒢csubscript𝒢𝑐\mathcal{G}_{c} is edge-capacitated and 𝒢osubscript𝒢𝑜\mathcal{G}_{o} is required to be undirected.

Prim’s algorithm [85] is an efficient algorithm to find an MST with complexity 𝒪​(|ℰc|+|𝒱|​log⁡|𝒱|)𝒪subscriptℰ𝑐𝒱𝒱\mathcal{O}(|\mathcal{E}_{c}|+|\mathcal{V}|\log|\mathcal{V}|) and then suited for the usual cross-silo scenarios with at most a few hundred nodes [41].

We have pointed out a simple algorithm when the overlay is undirected, but directed overlays can have arbitrarily shorter cycle times than undirected ones even in simple settings where all links in the underlay are bidirectional with identical delays in the two directions (see Appendix C). Unfortunately, computing optimal directed overlays is NP-hard:

Proposition 3.2.

Mct is NP-hard even when 𝒢csubscript𝒢𝑐\mathcal{G}_{c} is a complete Euclidean edge-capacitated graph.

We call a connectivity graph 𝒢csubscript𝒢𝑐\mathcal{G}_{c} Euclidean if its delays dc​(i,j)≜s×Tc​(i)+l​(i,j)+M/A​(i′,j′)≜subscript𝑑𝑐𝑖𝑗𝑠subscript𝑇𝑐𝑖𝑙𝑖𝑗𝑀𝐴superscript𝑖′superscript𝑗′d_{c}(i,j)\triangleq s\times T_{c}(i)+l(i,j)+M/A(i^{\prime},j^{\prime}) are symmetric (dc​(i,j)=dc​(j,i),∀i,j∈𝒱formulae-sequencesubscript𝑑𝑐𝑖𝑗subscript𝑑𝑐𝑗𝑖for-all𝑖𝑗𝒱d_{c}(i,j)=d_{c}(j,i),\forall i,j\in\mathcal{V}) and satisfy the triangle inequality (dc​(i,j)≤dc​(i,k)+dc​(k,j),∀i,j,k∈𝒱formulae-sequencesubscript𝑑𝑐𝑖𝑗subscript𝑑𝑐𝑖𝑘subscript𝑑𝑐𝑘𝑗for-all𝑖𝑗𝑘𝒱d_{c}(i,j)\leq d_{c}(i,k)+d_{c}(k,j),\forall i,j,k\in\mathcal{V}). These assumptions are roughly satisfied for geographically distant computing clusters with similar computation times, as the delay to transmit a message between two silos is roughly an affine function of the geodesic distance between them [32]. Under this condition Mct can be approximated:

Proposition 3.3.

Christofides’ algorithm [73] is a 3​N3𝑁3N-approximation algorithm for Mct when 𝒢csubscript𝒢𝑐\mathcal{G}_{c} is edge-capacitated and Euclidean.

The result follows from Christofides’ algorithm being a 1.5-approximation algorithm for the Travelling Salesman Problem [73], and our proof shows that a solution of the Travelling Salesman Problem provides a 2​N2𝑁2N-approximation of Mct. Note that Christofides’ algorithm finds ring topologies.

3.2 Node-capacitated networks

When silos do not enjoy high-speed connectivity, congestion at access links can become the dominant contribution to network delays, especially when one silo communicates with many others. Intuitively, in this setting, good overlays will exhibit small degrees.

If 𝒢osubscript𝒢𝑜\mathcal{G}_{o} is required to be undirected, Mct can be reduced from the problem of finding the minimum bottleneck spanning tree with bounded degree δ>1𝛿1\delta>1 (δ𝛿\delta-Mbst for short),222 A δ𝛿\delta-MBST is a spanning tree with degree at most δ𝛿\delta in which the largest edge delay is as small as possible. which is NP-hard.

Proposition 3.4.

In node-capacitated networks Mct is NP-hard even when the overlay is required to be undirected.

We propose Algorithm 1 (see Appendix D), which combines existing approximation algorithms for δ𝛿\delta-Mbst on a particular graph built from 𝒢csubscript𝒢𝑐\mathcal{G}_{c}.

Proposition 3.5.

Algorithm 1 is a 666-approximation algorithm for Mct when 𝒢csubscript𝒢𝑐\mathcal{G}_{c} is node-capacitated and Euclidean with CUP​(i)≤min⁡(CDN​(j)N,A​(i′,j′))subscript𝐶UP𝑖subscript𝐶DN𝑗𝑁𝐴superscript𝑖′superscript𝑗′C_{\textrm{UP}}(i)\leq\min\left(\frac{C_{\textrm{DN}}(j)}{N},A(i^{\prime},j^{\prime})\right), ∀(i,j)∈ℰcfor-all𝑖𝑗subscriptℰ𝑐\forall(i,j)\in\mathcal{E}_{c}, and 𝒢osubscript𝒢𝑜\mathcal{G}_{o} is required to be undirected.

Finding directed overlays is obviously an NP-hard problem also for node-capacitated networks. Christofides’ algorithm holds its approximation factor also in this more general case:

Proposition 3.6.

Christofides’ algorithm is a 3​N3𝑁3N-approximation algorithm for Mct when 𝒢csubscript𝒢𝑐\mathcal{G}_{c} is node-capacitated and Euclidean.

4 Numerical Experiments

We adapted PyTorch with the MPI backend to run DPASGD (see (2)) on a GPU cluster. We also developed a separate network simulator that takes as input an arbitrary underlay topology described in the Graph Modelling Language [36] and silos’ computation times and calculates the time instants at which local models 𝒘i​(k)subscript𝒘𝑖𝑘{\bm{w}}_{i}(k) are computed according to (2) (Appendix F). While PyTorch trains the model as fast as the cluster permits, the network simulator reconstructs the real timeline on the considered underlay. The code is available at https://github.com/omarfoq/communication-in-cross-silo-fl.

We considered three real topologies from Rocketfuel engine [94] (Exodus and Ebone) and from The Internet Topology Zoo [48] (Géant), and two synthetic topologies (AWS North-America and Gaia) built from the geographical locations of AWS data centers [38, 96] (Table 3). These topologies have between 11 and 87 nodes located in the same continent with the exception of Gaia, which spans four continents. We considered that each node is connected to a geographically close silo by a symmetric access link. See Appendixes G and H for a detailed description of the experiments and additional results.

We evaluated our solutions on three standard federated datasets from LEAF [14] and on iNaturalist dataset [99] with geolocalized images from over 8,000 different species of plants and animals (Table 2). For LEAF datasets, we generated non-iid data distributions following the procedure in [57]. For iNaturalist we assigned half of the images uniformly at random and half to the closest silo obtaining local datasets different in size and in the species represented (Appendix G).

Table 3 shows the effect of 6 different overlays when training ResNet-18 over iNaturalist in networks with capacities equal to 1 Gbps and 10 Gbps for core links and access links, respectively.333 The delay in the core network is determined by the available bandwidth as in (3). Available bandwidths are often limited to tens or hundreds of Mbps even over inter-datacenter links with capacities between 100 Gbps and 1 Tbps [38, 65, 83, 47]. By selecting 111 Gbps core links in our simulator, which ignores other traffic, we obtain available bandwidth distributions comparable to those observed in experimental studies like [38] (Appendix G). These overlays are (1) the STAR, corresponding to the usual server-client setting, where the orchestrator (located at the node with the highest load centrality [11]) averages all models at each communication round, (2) a dynamic topology built from MATCHA starting from the connectivity graph, (3) one built starting from the underlay and denoted as MATCHA+ (in both cases MATCHA’s parameter Cbsubscript𝐶𝑏C_{b} equals 0.50.50.5 as in experiments in  [104]444 Additional experiments fine tuning Cbsubscript𝐶𝑏C_{b} were carried out, conclusions remain the same (Appendix H.6). ), (4) the minimum spanning tree (MST) from Prop. 3.1, (5) the δ𝛿\delta-minimum bottleneck tree (δ𝛿\delta-MBST) from Prop. 3.5, and (6) the directed RING from Prop. 3.6. In this particular setting, δ𝛿\delta-MBST selects the same overlay as MST. The consensus matrix 𝑨𝑨{\bm{A}} is selected according to the local-degree rule [62].555Additional experiments were conducted selecting the matrix 𝑨𝑨{\bm{A}} as solution of the fastest distributed linear averaging problem defined in [62] (Appendix H.4).

The overlays found by our algorithms achieve a higher throughput (smaller cycle time) than the STAR (the server-client architecture) and, in most cases, than state-of-the-art MATCHA(+). 666 As MATCHA and MATCHA(+) select random overlays at each iteration, we compute their average cycle time. In particular, the RING is between 3.3 (≈391/118absent391118\approx 391/118 on Gaia) and 9.4 (≈902/95absent90295\approx 902/95 on Ebone) times faster than the STAR and between 1.5 and 6 times faster than MATCHA. MATCHA+ relies on the knowledge of the underlay—probably an unrealistic assumption in an Internet setting—while our algorithms only require information about the connectivity graph. Still, the RING is also faster than MATCHA+ but on Géant network (where MST is the fastest overlay). From now on, we show only the results for MATCHA+, as it outperforms MATCHA.

The final training time is the product of the cycle time and the number of communication rounds required to converge. The overlay also influences the number of communication rounds, with sparser overlays demanding more rounds [75, 24]. The last two columns in Table 3 show that this is a second order effect: the RING requires at most 20% more communication rounds than the STAR and then maintains almost the same relative performance in terms of the training time.777 Training time is evaluated as the time to reach a training accuracy equal to 65%percent6565\%, 55%percent5555\%, 55%percent5555\%, 50%percent5050\% and 50%percent5050\% for Gaia, AWS North America, Géant, Exodus, and Ebone networks, respectively. Note that data distribution is different in each network, so that a different global model is learned when solving Problem (1) (see explanations in Appendix H.5). These results (and those in Fig. 2) confirm that the number of communication rounds to converge is weakly sensitive to the topology (as already observed in [61, 60, 49, 66] and partially explained in [86, 5, 79]). The conclusion is that overlays should indeed be designed for throughput improvement rather than to optimize their spectral properties: the topologies selected by our algorithms achieve faster training time than the STAR, which has optimal spectral properties, and MATCHA/MATCHA(+), which optimize spectral properties given a communication budget.

The same qualitative results hold for other datasets and Fig. 2 shows the training loss versus the number of communication rounds (top row) and versus time (bottom row) when training on AWS North America with 100 times slower access links. Other metrics for model evaluation (e.g., training/test accuracy) are shown in Appendix H.2. The advantage of designing the topology on the basis of the underlay characteristics is evident also in this setting.

Figure 3 illustrates the effect of access link speeds on the cycle time and the training time. When all silos have the same access link capacity (Fig. 3(a)), for capacity values smaller than 6 Gbps, the RING has the largest throughput followed by δ𝛿\delta-MBST, MST and MATCHA+ almost paired, and finally the STAR. The advantage of topologies with small nodes’ degrees (like δ𝛿\delta-MBST and the RING) is someway expected in the slow access link regime, as access link delays become the dominant term in (3). In particular, Eq. (5) and some simple calculations in Appendix B show that, with N𝑁N silos, the RING is up to 2​N2𝑁2N (=80 for Géant) times faster than the STAR and Cb×max⁡(degree​(𝒢u))subscript𝐶𝑏degreesubscript𝒢𝑢C_{b}\times\max(\textrm{degree}(\mathcal{G}_{u})) (= 5 for Géant) times faster then MATCHA(+) for slow access links as confirmed in Fig. 3(a) (left plot). What is less expected (but aligned with our observations above about the importance to design overlays for throughput improvement) is that RING’s throughput speedups lead to almost as large training time speedups, even larger than those in Table 3: e.g. 72x in comparison to the STAR and 5.6x in comparison to MATCHA+ for 100 Mbps access link capacities.

When the most central node (which is also the center of the STAR) maintains a fixed capacity value equal to 101010 Gbps (Fig. 3(b)), the STAR performs better, but still is twice slower than the RING and only as fast as δ𝛿\delta-MBST. This result may appear surprising at first, but it is another consequence of Eq. (5) discussed in Appendix B. Again the relative performance of different overlays in terms of throughput is essentially maintained when looking at the final training time, with differences across topologies emerging only for those with very close throughputs, i.e., MST and MATCHA+, and STAR and δ𝛿\delta-MBST in the heterogeneous setting of Fig. 3(b).

When local computation requires less time than transmission of model updates, the silo may perform s𝑠s local computation steps before a communication round. As s𝑠s increases, the total computation time (s×Tc​(i)𝑠subscript𝑇𝑐𝑖s\times T_{c}(i)) becomes dominant in (3) and the throughput of different overlays become more and more similar (Fig. 4).888 In Appendix H.1, we show tables similar to Table 3 for different values of s𝑠s. Too many local steps may degrade the quality of the final model, and how to tune s𝑠s is still an open research area [106, 105, 102, 64, 108, 50]. Our next research goal is to study this aspect in conjunction with topology design. Intuitively, a faster overlay reduces the number of local steps needed to amortize the communication cost and may lead to better models given the available time budget for training.

5 Conclusions

We used the theory of max-plus linear systems to propose topology design algorithms that can significantly speed-up federated learning training by maximizing the system throughput. Our results show that this approach is more promising than targeting topologies with the best spectral properties, as MATCHA(+) does. In future work, we will explore how to further speed-up training, e.g., by enriching the topologies found by our algorithms with additional links that improve connectivity without decreasing the throughput, and by carefully optimizing the weights of the consensus matrix.

6 Broader Impact

We have proposed topology design algorithms that can significantly speed-up federated learning in a cross-silo setting. Improving the efficiency of federated learning can foster its adoption, allowing different entities to share datasets that otherwise would not be available for training.

Federated learning is intended to protect data privacy, as the data is not collected at a single point. At the same time a federated learning system, as any Internet-scale distributed system, may be more vulnerable to different attacks aiming to jeopardize training or to infer some characteristics of the local dataset by looking at the different messages [26, 92]. Encryption [10, 80, 8] and differential privacy [1] techniques may help preventing such attacks.

Federated learning is less efficient than training in a highly-optimized computing cluster. It may in particular increase energy training costs, due to a more discontinuous usage of local computing resources and the additional cost of transmitting messages over long distance links. To the best of our knowledge, energetic considerations for federated learning have not been adequately explored, but for a few papers considering FL for mobile devices [42, 97].

Appendix A Graph Theory

We now list concepts of graph theory which will be used later on.

  • •

    Predecessor, successor, neighbour: If in a graph (i,j)∈ℰ𝑖𝑗ℰ(i,j)\in\mathcal{E}, then i𝑖i is called a predecessor of j𝑗j, j𝑗j is called a successor of i𝑖i and j𝑗j, resp. i𝑖i is called a neighbour of i𝑖i , resp. j𝑗j. The set of predecessors of j𝑗j is indicated by π​(j)𝜋𝑗\pi(j) (or 𝒩j+subscriptsuperscript𝒩𝑗\mathcal{N}^{+}_{j}), the set of all successors of i𝑖i is denoted σ​(i)𝜎𝑖\sigma(i) (or 𝒩i−subscriptsuperscript𝒩𝑖\mathcal{N}^{-}_{i}) and the set of neighbours of i𝑖i is denoted 𝒩isubscript𝒩𝑖\mathcal{N}_{i}. Note that in the case of undirected graphs, 𝒩i=π​(i)=σ​(i)subscript𝒩𝑖𝜋𝑖𝜎𝑖\mathcal{N}_{i}=\pi(i)=\sigma(i).

  • •

    Path, circuit: A path is a sequence of nodes (i1,…,ip),p>1subscript𝑖1…subscript𝑖𝑝𝑝1(i_{1},\dots,i_{p}),p>1, such that ij∈π​(ij+1),j=1,…,p−1formulae-sequencesubscript𝑖𝑗𝜋subscript𝑖𝑗1𝑗1…𝑝1i_{j}\in\pi(i_{j+1}),j=1,\dots,p-1. An elementary path is a path where no node appears more then once. When the initial node and the final node coincide, we call the path a circuit. A circuit C=(i1,…,ip=i1)𝐶subscript𝑖1…subscript𝑖𝑝subscript𝑖1C=(i_{1},\dots,i_{p}=i_{1}) is an elementary circuit if the path (i1,…,ip−1)subscript𝑖1…subscript𝑖𝑝1(i_{1},\dots,i_{p-1}) is elementary, an elementary circuit is sometimes referred to as a cycle. If a cycle spans all vertices of the graph it is called a Hamiltonian cycle. The length of circuit C=(i1,…,ip)𝐶subscript𝑖1…subscript𝑖𝑝C=(i_{1},\dots,i_{p}) is the number of the arcs of which it is composed, i.e., |C|=p𝐶𝑝|C|=p, and its weight is the sum of the weights of its arcs, i.e, d​(C)=∑k=1p−1d​(ik,ik+1)𝑑𝐶superscriptsubscript𝑘1𝑝1𝑑subscript𝑖𝑘subscript𝑖𝑘1d(C)=\sum_{k=1}^{p-1}d(i_{k},i_{k+1}).

  • •

    Subgraph, spanning subgraph: Given a graph 𝒢=(𝒱,ℰ)𝒢𝒱ℰ\mathcal{G}=(\mathcal{V},\mathcal{E}), a graph 𝒢′=(𝒱′,ℰ′)superscript𝒢′superscript𝒱′superscriptℰ′\mathcal{G}^{\prime}=(\mathcal{V}^{\prime},\mathcal{E}^{\prime}) is said to be a subgraph of 𝒢𝒢\mathcal{G} if 𝒱′⊂𝒱superscript𝒱′𝒱\mathcal{V}^{\prime}\subset\mathcal{V} and ℰ⊂ℰ′ℰsuperscriptℰ′\mathcal{E}\subset\mathcal{E}^{\prime}. 𝒢′superscript𝒢′\mathcal{G}^{\prime} is said to be a spanning subgraph if 𝒱′=𝒱superscript𝒱′𝒱\mathcal{V}^{\prime}=\mathcal{V}.

  • •

    Strongly connected graph: A digraph is said to be strongly connected or strong if for any two different nodes i𝑖i and j𝑗j in 𝒱𝒱\mathcal{V} there exists a path from i𝑖i to j𝑗j.

  • •

    Optimal tour: In a Hamiltonian graph (i.e., a graph having a Hamiltonian cycle) a Hamiltonian cycle with minimum weight is called an optimal tour. Finding the optimal tour in a complete graph is a well known problem and is referred to as the Traveling Salesman Problem (TSP), see for example [4].

  • •

    Tree, acyclic graph, and Minimum Spanning Tree (MST): A tree, or equivalently a connected acyclic undirected graph, is an undirected graph in which any two vertices are connected by exactly one path. An acyclic graph 𝒯𝒯\mathcal{T} is said to be a spanning tree of an undirected graph 𝒢𝒢\mathcal{G} if 𝒯𝒯\mathcal{T} is a connected spanning subgraph of 𝒢𝒢\mathcal{G}. 𝒯𝒯\mathcal{T} is said to be an MST of 𝒢𝒢\mathcal{G} if it has minimal weight (the weight of a tree is the sum of the weights of all its edges) among all spanning trees of 𝒢𝒢\mathcal{G}.

  • •

    Cut, cut-set, and cut property: A cut is a partition of the vertices of a graph into two disjoint subsets. For a cut c𝑐c, the cut-set is the set of edges connecting two nodes from the two disjoint subsets. In a tree, deleting an edge, induces a partition of the set of vertices. For any cut c𝑐c of the graph, if the weight of an edge e𝑒e in the cut-set of c𝑐c is strictly smaller than the weights of all other edges of the cut-set of c𝑐c, then this edge belongs to all MSTs of the graph.

Appendix B On STAR and MATCHA(+) Cycle Times

For a graph 𝒢𝒢\mathcal{G}, let degree​(i,𝒢)degree𝑖𝒢\textrm{degree}(i,\mathcal{G}) denote the degree node i𝑖i in 𝒢𝒢\mathcal{G} and max⁡(degree​(𝒢))degree𝒢\max(\textrm{degree}(\mathcal{G})) denote the maximum degree of the nodes in 𝒢𝒢\mathcal{G}. We show that, with N𝑁N silos, the RING is up to 2​N2𝑁2N times faster than the STAR and approximately Cb×max⁡(degree​(𝒢u))subscript𝐶𝑏degreesubscript𝒢𝑢C_{b}\times\max(\textrm{degree}(\mathcal{G}_{u})) times faster then MATCHA(+) for slow homogeneous access links as shown also in Fig. 3(a).

Since access links are homogeneous, i.e., CUP​(i)=CDN​(i)=CUP​(j)=CDN​(j)=C,∀i,j∈𝒱formulae-sequencesubscript𝐶UP𝑖subscript𝐶DN𝑖subscript𝐶UP𝑗subscript𝐶DN𝑗𝐶for-all𝑖𝑗𝒱C_{\textrm{UP}}(i)=C_{\textrm{DN}}(i)=C_{\textrm{UP}}(j)=C_{\textrm{DN}}(j)=C,\forall i,j\in\mathcal{V}, and slow access links determine the delays, i.e., CUP​(i)≪A​(i′,j′)much-less-thansubscript𝐶UP𝑖𝐴superscript𝑖′superscript𝑗′C_{\textrm{UP}}(i)\ll A(i^{\prime},j^{\prime}) and s×Tc​(i)+l​(i,j)≪MA​(i,j)much-less-than𝑠subscript𝑇𝑐𝑖𝑙𝑖𝑗𝑀𝐴𝑖𝑗s\times T_{c}(i)+l(i,j)\ll\frac{M}{A(i,j)}, according to (3), we have:

do​(i,j)=max⁡(|𝒩i−|,|𝒩j+|)×MC.subscript𝑑𝑜𝑖𝑗superscriptsubscript𝒩𝑖superscriptsubscript𝒩𝑗𝑀𝐶d_{o}(i,j)=\max\left(|\mathcal{N}_{i}^{-}|,|\mathcal{N}_{j}^{+}|\right)\times\frac{M}{C}.

Then, the cycle time of the RING can be obtained from (5):

τRING=∑i=1Ndo​(i,i+1)N=MC×NN=MC.subscript𝜏RINGsuperscriptsubscript𝑖1𝑁subscript𝑑𝑜𝑖𝑖1𝑁𝑀𝐶𝑁𝑁𝑀𝐶\tau_{\text{RING}}=\frac{\sum_{i=1}^{N}d_{o}(i,i+1)}{N}=\frac{\frac{M}{C}\times N}{N}=\frac{M}{C}.

Remember that a cycle is the time interval between two consecutive computations at a given silo. For the STAR, it corresponds to the time interval between when the central node sends the new aggregate model to all silos and when it receives all updated local models. Therefore, we have:

τSTAR=MC×N+MC×N=2​N×MC.subscript𝜏STAR𝑀𝐶𝑁𝑀𝐶𝑁2𝑁𝑀𝐶\tau_{\textrm{STAR}}=\frac{M}{C}\times N+\frac{M}{C}\times N=2N\times\frac{M}{C}.

For MATCHA+, at each communication round, we select a random subgraph 𝒢𝒢\mathcal{G}. Let degree​(i,𝒢)degree𝑖𝒢\textrm{degree}(i,\mathcal{G}) denote the degree of silo i𝑖i in 𝒢𝒢\mathcal{G}. If 𝒢𝒢\mathcal{G} is drawn, the duration of the communication round is M/C×max⁡(degree​(𝒢))𝑀𝐶degree𝒢M/C\times\max(\textrm{degree}(\mathcal{G})). The cycle time is then

τMATCHA+=MC​𝔼𝒢​[max⁡degree​(𝒢)].subscript𝜏superscriptMATCHA𝑀𝐶subscript𝔼𝒢delimited-[]degree𝒢\tau_{\textrm{MATCHA}^{+}}=\frac{M}{C}\mathbb{E}_{\mathcal{G}}\left[\max\textrm{degree}(\mathcal{G})\right].

Let j𝑗j be the silo such that j′superscript𝑗′j^{\prime} has the largest degree in 𝒢usubscript𝒢𝑢\mathcal{G}_{u}. MATCHA+ uses max⁡(degree​(𝒢u))+1degreesubscript𝒢𝑢1\max(\textrm{degree}(\mathcal{G}_{u}))+1 matchings. The edges of j𝑗j belong to different matchings. As MATCHA+ activates at any communication round a fraction Cbsubscript𝐶𝑏C_{b} of all matchings, the average degree of node j𝑗j is 𝔼𝒢​[degree​(j,𝒢)]≈Cb×degree​(j,𝒢u)=Cb×max⁡(degree​(𝒢u))subscript𝔼𝒢delimited-[]degree𝑗𝒢subscript𝐶𝑏degree𝑗subscript𝒢𝑢subscript𝐶𝑏degreesubscript𝒢𝑢\mathbb{E}_{\mathcal{G}}\left[\textrm{degree}(j,\mathcal{G})\right]\approx C_{b}\times\textrm{degree}(j,\mathcal{G}_{u})=C_{b}\times\max(\textrm{degree}(\mathcal{G}_{u})). Then

τMATCHA+⪆MC×Cb×max⁡(degree​(𝒢u)).greater-than-or-approximately-equalssubscript𝜏superscriptMATCHA𝑀𝐶subscript𝐶𝑏degreesubscript𝒢𝑢\tau_{\textrm{MATCHA}^{+}}\gtrapprox\frac{M}{C}\times C_{b}\times\max(\textrm{degree}(\mathcal{G}_{u})).

Appendix C Directed Overlays may be Faster than Undirected Overlays

We provide two examples where the underlay network is undirected and still a directed overlay can have shorter cycle time than directed overlays. Examples are in Fig. 5, where numbers associated to links are the corresponding delays (in the two directions).

The network in Fig. 5(a) has only three nodes, 𝒱={1,2,3}𝒱123\mathcal{V}=\{1,2,3\}. We have dc​(1,2)=dc​(2,1)=1subscript𝑑𝑐12subscript𝑑𝑐211d_{c}(1,2)=d_{c}(2,1)=1, dc​(2,3)=dc​(3,2)=3subscript𝑑𝑐23subscript𝑑𝑐323d_{c}(2,3)=d_{c}(3,2)=3, and dc​(1,3)=dc​(3,1)=4subscript𝑑𝑐13subscript𝑑𝑐314d_{c}(1,3)=d_{c}(3,1)=4. The fastest undirected overlay is Go(u)=(𝒱,{(1,2),(2,3)})superscriptsubscript𝐺𝑜𝑢𝒱1223G_{o}^{(u)}=(\mathcal{V},\{(1,2),(2,3)\}). Consider the directed ring Go=(𝒱,{(1,2),(2,3),(3,1)})subscript𝐺𝑜𝒱122331G_{o}=(\mathcal{V},\{(1,2),(2,3),(3,1)\}). We have:

τ​(𝒢o(u))=max⁡(1+12,3+32,1+3+1+34)=3,𝜏superscriptsubscript𝒢𝑜𝑢112332131343\displaystyle\tau\left(\mathcal{G}_{o}^{(u)}\right)=\max\left(\frac{1+1}{2},\frac{3+3}{2},\frac{1+3+1+3}{4}\right)=3, (7)
τ​(𝒢o)=1+3+(3+1)3=83<3.𝜏subscript𝒢𝑜13313833\displaystyle\tau\left(\mathcal{G}_{o}\right)=\frac{1+3+(3+1)}{3}=\frac{8}{3}<3. (8)

The network in Fig. 5(b) shows that a directed ring can be arbitrarily faster than an undirected one. Similarly to above, the fastest undirected overlay is Go(u)superscriptsubscript𝐺𝑜𝑢G_{o}^{(u)} and coincides with the underlay. The directed overlay is the ring (1→2→3→…​n→n+1→1)→12→3→…𝑛→𝑛1→1(1\to 2\to 3\to\dots n\to n+1\to 1). We have

τ​(𝒢o(u))=n,𝜏superscriptsubscript𝒢𝑜𝑢𝑛\displaystyle\tau\left(\mathcal{G}_{o}^{(u)}\right)=n, (9)
τ​(𝒢o)=(n−1)×1+n+(n+(n−1)×1)n+1=4​n−2n+1<4.𝜏subscript𝒢𝑜𝑛11𝑛𝑛𝑛11𝑛14𝑛2𝑛14\displaystyle\tau\left(\mathcal{G}_{o}\right)=\frac{(n-1)\times 1+n+(n+(n-1)\times 1)}{n+1}=\frac{4n-2}{n+1}<4. (10)

The ratio of the two cycle times can be made arbitrarily large.

Appendix D Approximation Algorithm for Mct on Node-Capacitated Networks

In this section, we describe Algorithm 1 that provides an approximate solution for Mct when the network is node-capacitated and 𝒢csubscript𝒢𝑐\mathcal{G}_{c} is complete. Algorithm 1 combines existing approximation algorithms for δ𝛿\delta-Mbst on a particular undirected graph built from 𝒢csubscript𝒢𝑐\mathcal{G}_{c} and denoted by 𝒢c(u)subscriptsuperscript𝒢𝑢𝑐\mathcal{G}^{(u)}_{c} (lines 1-1). Lemma E.5 establishes a connection between the bottleneck of the Mbst of 𝒢c(u)subscriptsuperscript𝒢𝑢𝑐\mathcal{G}^{(u)}_{c} and the cycle time of Mct on 𝒢csubscript𝒢𝑐\mathcal{G}_{c} when the overlay is required to be undirected. To get an approximated 222-Mbst on 𝒢c(u)subscriptsuperscript𝒢𝑢𝑐\mathcal{G}^{(u)}_{c}, we apply the best known 333-approximation algorithm from [3, Sect. 3.2.1] (lines 1-1) which requires 𝒢c(u)subscriptsuperscript𝒢𝑢𝑐\mathcal{G}^{(u)}_{c} to be Euclidean (Lemma E.6), and take its result as one candidate for our solution (line 1). The cube of a graph 𝒢𝒢\mathcal{G}, denoted by 𝒢3superscript𝒢3\mathcal{G}^{3}, is the super-graph of 𝒢𝒢\mathcal{G} such that the edge (u𝑢u, v𝑣v) is in 𝒢3superscript𝒢3\mathcal{G}^{3} if and only if there is a path between u𝑢u and v𝑣v in 𝒢𝒢\mathcal{G} with three or fewer edges. It has been proved that the cube of a connected graph is Hamiltonian and to find a Hamiltonian path in such a cube can be done in polynomial time [43]. Other δ𝛿\delta-BSTs built by Algorithm 2 for 3≤δ≤N3𝛿𝑁3\leq\delta\leq N are considered as candidates (lines 1-1) and we finally provide as solution the overlay with the smallest cycle time (line 1).

Appendix E Proofs

We use some graph terminology and notation introduced in Appendix A.

E.1 Proof of Proposition 3.1

When we require the overlay 𝒢osubscript𝒢𝑜\mathcal{G}_{o} to be undirected, if we include link (i,j)∈𝒢c𝑖𝑗subscript𝒢𝑐(i,j)\in\mathcal{G}_{c} then we will also include link (j,i)𝑗𝑖(j,i). It is then convenient to consider the undirected graph 𝒢c(u)=(𝒱,ℰc(u))superscriptsubscript𝒢𝑐𝑢𝒱superscriptsubscriptℰ𝑐𝑢\mathcal{G}_{c}^{(u)}=(\mathcal{V},\mathcal{E}_{c}^{(u)}), where (i,j)∈ℰc(u)𝑖𝑗superscriptsubscriptℰ𝑐𝑢(i,j)\in\mathcal{E}_{c}^{(u)} iff (i,j)∈ℰc𝑖𝑗subscriptℰ𝑐(i,j)\in\mathcal{E}_{c} and (j,i)∈ℰc𝑗𝑖subscriptℰ𝑐(j,i)\in\mathcal{E}_{c}, from which we want to extract an undirected strong subgraph 𝒢osubscript𝒢𝑜\mathcal{G}_{o} with minimal cycle time. We also associate to each edge (i,j)∈𝒢c(u)𝑖𝑗superscriptsubscript𝒢𝑐𝑢(i,j)\in\mathcal{G}_{c}^{(u)} the weight dc(u)​(i,j)=(dc​(i,j)+dc​(j,i))/2superscriptsubscript𝑑𝑐𝑢𝑖𝑗subscript𝑑𝑐𝑖𝑗subscript𝑑𝑐𝑗𝑖2d_{c}^{(u)}(i,j)=(d_{c}(i,j)+d_{c}(j,i))/2. Remember that dc​(i,j)subscript𝑑𝑐𝑖𝑗d_{c}(i,j) is defined as follows

dc​(i,j)≜s×Tc​(i)+l​(i,j)+M/A​(i′,j′).≜subscript𝑑𝑐𝑖𝑗𝑠subscript𝑇𝑐𝑖𝑙𝑖𝑗𝑀𝐴superscript𝑖′superscript𝑗′d_{c}(i,j)\triangleq s\times T_{c}(i)+l(i,j)+M/A(i^{\prime},j^{\prime}).

Note that an undirected weighted graph can be also seen as a particular directed graph where for each link (i,j)𝑖𝑗(i,j) in one direction, there exists a link (j,i)𝑗𝑖(j,i) with the opposite direction and the same weight. The concept of cycle time can then immediately be extended to undirected graphs.

Lemma E.1.

Consider the undirected weighted graph 𝒢c(u)=(𝒱,ℰc(u))superscriptsubscript𝒢𝑐𝑢𝒱superscriptsubscriptℰ𝑐𝑢\mathcal{G}_{c}^{(u)}=(\mathcal{V},\mathcal{E}_{c}^{(u)}), where (i,j)∈ℰc(u)𝑖𝑗superscriptsubscriptℰ𝑐𝑢(i,j)\in\mathcal{E}_{c}^{(u)} iff (i,j)∈ℰc𝑖𝑗subscriptℰ𝑐(i,j)\in\mathcal{E}_{c} and (j,i)∈ℰc𝑗𝑖subscriptℰ𝑐(j,i)\in\mathcal{E}_{c}. When 𝒢csubscript𝒢𝑐\mathcal{G}_{c} is edge-capacitated and 𝒢osubscript𝒢𝑜\mathcal{G}_{o} is required to be undirected, the set of solutions Mct includes a spanning tree of 𝒢c(u)superscriptsubscript𝒢𝑐𝑢\mathcal{G}_{c}^{(u)}.

Proof.

Mct is a discrete optimization problem on a finite set,999 The set of subgraphs of an undirected graph 𝒢csubscript𝒢𝑐\mathcal{G}_{c} is finite. thus the set of solutions of Mct is non-empty. Suppose by contradiction that the set of solutions does not contain any spanning tree of 𝒢csubscript𝒢𝑐\mathcal{G}_{c} and consider 𝒢o∗superscriptsubscript𝒢𝑜\mathcal{G}_{o}^{*} to be one of such solutions.

As 𝒢o∗superscriptsubscript𝒢𝑜\mathcal{G}_{o}^{*} is not a spanning tree and it is strongly connected, there exist circuits in 𝒢o∗superscriptsubscript𝒢𝑜\mathcal{G}_{o}^{*}. For any circuit C=(i1,i2,…,ip=i1)𝐶subscript𝑖1subscript𝑖2…subscript𝑖𝑝subscript𝑖1C=(i_{1},i_{2},\dots,i_{p}=i_{1}) in 𝒢o∗superscriptsubscript𝒢𝑜\mathcal{G}_{o}^{*}, we consider the edge eCsubscript𝑒𝐶e_{C}, such that dc(u)​(eC)=maxk=1,…,p−1⁡dc(u)​(ik,ik+1)superscriptsubscript𝑑𝑐𝑢subscript𝑒𝐶subscript𝑘1…𝑝1superscriptsubscript𝑑𝑐𝑢subscript𝑖𝑘subscript𝑖𝑘1d_{c}^{(u)}(e_{C})=\max_{k=1,\dots,p-1}d_{c}^{(u)}(i_{k},i_{k+1}). The graph 𝒢^o∗superscriptsubscript^𝒢𝑜\hat{\mathcal{G}}_{o}^{*} obtained from 𝒢o∗superscriptsubscript𝒢𝑜\mathcal{G}_{o}^{*} by deleting eCsubscript𝑒𝐶e_{C} is a connected spanning subgraph of 𝒢c(u)superscriptsubscript𝒢𝑐𝑢\mathcal{G}_{c}^{(u)} and its cycle time is not greater then the cycle time of 𝒢o∗subscriptsuperscript𝒢𝑜\mathcal{G}^{*}_{o}. We can now proceed in the same way on 𝒢^o∗superscriptsubscript^𝒢𝑜\hat{\mathcal{G}}_{o}^{*} until the residual graph has no more circuits and it is then a spanning tree of 𝒢c(u)superscriptsubscript𝒢𝑐𝑢\mathcal{G}_{c}^{(u)} with cycle time not greater than the cycle time of 𝒢o∗subscriptsuperscript𝒢𝑜\mathcal{G}^{*}_{o}. This tree is also a solution of Mct contradicting the fact that no spanning tree is in the set of solutions. ∎

Lemma E.2.

Proposition 3.1.

Consider an undirected weighted graph 𝒢c(u)=(𝒱,ℰc(u))superscriptsubscript𝒢𝑐𝑢𝒱superscriptsubscriptℰ𝑐𝑢\mathcal{G}_{c}^{(u)}=(\mathcal{V},\mathcal{E}_{c}^{(u)}), where (i,j)∈ℰc(u)𝑖𝑗superscriptsubscriptℰ𝑐𝑢(i,j)\in\mathcal{E}_{c}^{(u)} iff (i,j)∈ℰc𝑖𝑗subscriptℰ𝑐(i,j)\in\mathcal{E}_{c} and (j,i)∈ℰc𝑗𝑖subscriptℰ𝑐(j,i)\in\mathcal{E}_{c} and where (i,j)∈ℰc(u)𝑖𝑗superscriptsubscriptℰ𝑐𝑢(i,j)\in\mathcal{E}_{c}^{(u)} has weight dc(u)​(i,j)=(do​(i,j)+do​(j,i))/2superscriptsubscript𝑑𝑐𝑢𝑖𝑗subscript𝑑𝑜𝑖𝑗subscript𝑑𝑜𝑗𝑖2d_{c}^{(u)}(i,j)=(d_{o}(i,j)+d_{o}(j,i))/2. E.2 Proof of Proposition 3.2

Proposition 3.2.

Mct is NP-hard even when 𝒢csubscript𝒢𝑐\mathcal{G}_{c} is a complete Euclidean edge-capacitated graph.

Proof.

When 𝒢csubscript𝒢𝑐\mathcal{G}_{c} is an edge-capacitated graph, dc​(i,j)=s×Tc​(i)+l​(i,j)+MA​(i′,j′)subscript𝑑𝑐𝑖𝑗𝑠subscript𝑇𝑐𝑖𝑙𝑖𝑗𝑀𝐴superscript𝑖′superscript𝑗′d_{c}(i,j)=s\times T_{c}(i)+l(i,j)+\frac{M}{A(i^{\prime},j^{\prime})}. 𝒢csubscript𝒢𝑐\mathcal{G}_{c} is complete and Euclidean means that dc​(i,j)=dc​(j,i)subscript𝑑𝑐𝑖𝑗subscript𝑑𝑐𝑗𝑖d_{c}(i,j)=d_{c}(j,i), for all (i,j)∈𝒱×𝒱𝑖𝑗𝒱𝒱(i,j)\in\mathcal{V}\times\mathcal{V} and that dcsubscript𝑑𝑐d_{c} verifies triangular inequality, i.e., dc​(i,j)≤dc​(i,k)+dc​(k,j)subscript𝑑𝑐𝑖𝑗subscript𝑑𝑐𝑖𝑘subscript𝑑𝑐𝑘𝑗d_{c}(i,j)\leq d_{c}(i,k)+d_{c}(k,j), for every i,j,k∈𝒱𝑖𝑗𝑘𝒱i,j,k\in\mathcal{V}.

We consider the decision problem Mct-Decision associated to the particular case of Mct when 𝒢csubscript𝒢𝑐\mathcal{G}_{c} is an Euclidean edge-capacitated graph and we prove that it is NP-complete.

{problem}

We first prove that Mct-Decision is NP.101010A decision problem is NP if we can verify in a polynomial time that the answer for a given instance is YES. Several algorithms (e.g., Karp’s Algorithm [20]) determines the cycle time of a given graph in a polynomial time. Thus for a proposed solution of Mct-Decision, we can compute its cycle time in polynomial time, and we can verify if the graph is strongly connected using for example depth first search. It follows that Mct-Decision is NP.

To prove that Mct-Decision is NP-complete, we show that Hamiltonian Cycle (Hc) can be reduced in a polynomial time to Mct-Decision, i.e., Hc≤pMct-Decisionsubscript𝑝HcMct-Decision\textsc{Hc}\leq_{p}\textsc{Mct-Decision}.

Hamiltonian cycle problem is the following decision problem:

{problem}

Given an instance of Hc with an undirected graph 𝒟=(𝒱,ℰ)𝒟𝒱ℰ\mathcal{D}=(\mathcal{V},\mathcal{E}), we construct an instance of Mct-Decision with a complete digraph 𝒢c=(𝒱,𝒱×𝒱)subscript𝒢𝑐𝒱𝒱𝒱\mathcal{G}_{c}=(\mathcal{V},\mathcal{V}\times\mathcal{V}), a real number τ0=N+2Nsubscript𝜏0𝑁2𝑁\tau_{0}=\frac{N+2}{N} where N𝑁N is the size of 𝒱𝒱\mathcal{V}, and delay function dcsubscript𝑑𝑐d_{c}, where for a given arbitrary choice of vertex v0subscript𝑣0v_{0}, dcsubscript𝑑𝑐d_{c} is defined as:

dc(i,j)={1if ((i,j)∈ℰ)∧(j≠v0)∧(i≠v0), 2if (((i,j)∈ℰ)∧((j=v0)∨(i=v0))) ∨ (((i,j)∉ℰ)∧(j≠v0)∧(i≠v0)),3if ((i,j)∉ℰ)∧((j=v0)∨(i=v0)).d_{c}(i,j)=\left\{\begin{matrix}[l]1&\text{if $\left((i,j)\in\mathcal{E}\right)\land\left(j\not=v_{0}\right)\land\left(i\not=v_{0}\right)$, }\\ 2&\text{if $\left(\left((i,j)\in\mathcal{E}\right)\land\left(\left(j=v_{0}\right)\lor\left(i=v_{0}\right)\right)\right)$ $\lor$ $\left(\left((i,j)\notin\mathcal{E}\right)\land\left(j\not=v_{0}\right){\land(i\not=v_{0})}\right),$}\\ 3&\text{if ${((i,j)\notin\mathcal{E})\land((j=v_{0})\lor(i=v_{0}))}$}.\end{matrix}\right.

The constructed digraph 𝒢csubscript𝒢𝑐\mathcal{G}_{c} is complete and the delays are symmetric and verify triangular inequality. In fact for three distinct nodes i,j𝑖𝑗i,j, and k𝑘k in 𝒱𝒱\mathcal{V}, we prove that dc​(i,j)≤dc​(i,k)+dc​(k,j)subscript𝑑𝑐𝑖𝑗subscript𝑑𝑐𝑖𝑘subscript𝑑𝑐𝑘𝑗d_{c}(i,j)\leq d_{c}(i,k)+d_{c}(k,j) by distinguishing three possible cases:

  1. 1.

    If i≠v0𝑖subscript𝑣0i\not=v_{0} and j≠v0𝑗subscript𝑣0j\not=v_{0}, then dc​(i,j)≤2subscript𝑑𝑐𝑖𝑗2d_{c}(i,j)\leq 2, but every delay is at least equal to one and then 2≤dc​(i,k)+dc​(k,j)2subscript𝑑𝑐𝑖𝑘subscript𝑑𝑐𝑘𝑗2\leq d_{c}(i,k)+d_{c}(k,j); it follows that dc​(i,j)≤dc​(i,k)+dc​(k,j)subscript𝑑𝑐𝑖𝑗subscript𝑑𝑐𝑖𝑘subscript𝑑𝑐𝑘𝑗d_{c}(i,j)\leq d_{c}(i,k)+d_{c}(k,j).

  2. 2.

    If i=v0𝑖subscript𝑣0i=v_{0}, then dc​(v0,k)≥2subscript𝑑𝑐subscript𝑣0𝑘2d_{c}(v_{0},k)\geq 2, thus dc​(v0,k)+dc​(k,j)≥3subscript𝑑𝑐subscript𝑣0𝑘subscript𝑑𝑐𝑘𝑗3d_{c}(v_{0},k)+d_{c}(k,j)\geq 3. It follows that dc​(v0,j)≤3≤dc​(v0,k)+dc​(k,j)subscript𝑑𝑐subscript𝑣0𝑗3subscript𝑑𝑐subscript𝑣0𝑘subscript𝑑𝑐𝑘𝑗d_{c}(v_{0},j)\leq 3\leq d_{c}(v_{0},k)+d_{c}(k,j).

  3. 3.

    The case when j=v0𝑗subscript𝑣0j=v_{0} is analogous to the case when i=v0𝑖subscript𝑣0i=v_{0}.

If 𝒟𝒟\mathcal{D} has a Hamiltonian cycle, then the (directed) graph induced by this cycle is a strong spanning subdigraph of 𝒢csubscript𝒢𝑐\mathcal{G}_{c} and its cycle time is τHc=1×(N−2)+2+2N=N+2N≤τ0subscript𝜏Hc1𝑁222𝑁𝑁2𝑁subscript𝜏0\tau_{\textsc{Hc}}=\frac{1\times(N-2)+2+2}{N}=\frac{N+2}{N}\leq\tau_{0}.

If 𝒢csubscript𝒢𝑐\mathcal{G}_{c} has a strong spanning sub-digraph, say 𝒢∗superscript𝒢\mathcal{G}^{*}, having a cycle time τ∗≤N+2Nsuperscript𝜏𝑁2𝑁\tau^{*}\leq\frac{N+2}{N}, let C𝐶C be an elementary circuit of 𝒢∗superscript𝒢\mathcal{G}^{*} containing v0subscript𝑣0v_{0} (such a circuit always exists because the graph is strongly connected). By definition of cycle time, dc​(C)|C|≤τ∗=1+2Nsubscript𝑑𝑐𝐶𝐶superscript𝜏12𝑁\frac{d_{c}(C)}{|C|}\leq\tau^{*}=1+\frac{2}{N} . We are going to prove that C𝐶C is a Hamiltonian cycle of 𝒟𝒟\mathcal{D}.

We prove first by contradiction that C𝐶C contains only the arcs from ℰℰ\mathcal{E}. Suppose by contradiction that there exists an arc (i,j)∉ℰ𝑖𝑗ℰ(i,j)\notin\mathcal{E} in C𝐶C, two cases are possible:

  1. 1.

    If j≠v0𝑗subscript𝑣0j\not=v_{0}, and i≠v0𝑖subscript𝑣0i\not=v_{0} then dc​(i,j)=2subscript𝑑𝑐𝑖𝑗2{d_{c}(i,j)=2} and since v0∈Csubscript𝑣0𝐶v_{0}\in C, there exist two nodes v0−∈σ​(v0)subscriptsuperscript𝑣0𝜎subscript𝑣0v^{-}_{0}\in\sigma(v_{0}) and v0+∈π​(v0)subscriptsuperscript𝑣0𝜋subscript𝑣0v^{+}_{0}\in\pi(v_{0}) in C𝐶C.     If i=v0𝑖subscript𝑣0i=v_{0}, let v0+superscriptsubscript𝑣0v_{0}^{+} be the predecessor of v0subscript𝑣0v_{0} in C𝐶C, it follows that dc​(C)≥dc​(v0+,v0)+d​(v0,j)+1×(|C|−2)≥3+2+|C|−2=3+|C|subscript𝑑𝑐𝐶subscript𝑑𝑐superscriptsubscript𝑣0subscript𝑣0𝑑subscript𝑣0𝑗1𝐶232𝐶23𝐶d_{c}(C)\geq d_{c}(v_{0}^{+},v_{0})+d(v_{0},j)+1\times(|C|-2)\geq 3+2+|C|-2=3+|C|, thus dc​(C)|C|≥1+3|C|subscript𝑑𝑐𝐶𝐶13𝐶\frac{d_{c}(C)}{|C|}\geq 1+\frac{3}{|C|}, and using the same argument as for the first case we get a contradiction.

  3. 3.

    The case when j=v0𝑗subscript𝑣0j=v_{0} is analogous to the case when i=v0𝑖subscript𝑣0i=v_{0}.

It follows that any arc of C𝐶C is in ℰℰ\mathcal{E}.

We prove next that C𝐶C is a Hamiltonian Cycle, i.e., |C|=N𝐶𝑁|C|=N. Since v0∈Csubscript𝑣0𝐶v_{0}\in C, there exist two nodes v0+∈σ​(v0)subscriptsuperscript𝑣0𝜎subscript𝑣0v^{+}_{0}\in\sigma(v_{0}) and v0−∈π​(v0)subscriptsuperscript𝑣0𝜋subscript𝑣0v^{-}_{0}\in\pi(v_{0}) in C𝐶C, it follows that dc​(C)=dc​(v0−,v0)+dc​(v0,v0+)+1×(|C|−2)=2+2+|C|−2=2+|C|subscript𝑑𝑐𝐶subscript𝑑𝑐subscriptsuperscript𝑣0subscript𝑣0subscript𝑑𝑐subscript𝑣0subscriptsuperscript𝑣01𝐶222𝐶22𝐶d_{c}(C)=d_{c}(v^{-}_{0},v_{0})+d_{c}(v_{0},v^{+}_{0})+1\times(|C|-2)=2+2+|C|-2=2+|C|.

Since dc​(C)|C|≤τ∗=1+2Nsubscript𝑑𝑐𝐶𝐶superscript𝜏12𝑁\frac{d_{c}(C)}{|C|}\leq\tau^{*}=1+\frac{2}{N}, it follows that 1+2|C|≤1+2N12𝐶12𝑁1+\frac{2}{|C|}\leq 1+\frac{2}{N}, thus |C|≥N𝐶𝑁|C|\geq N. As C𝐶C is an elementary circuit it follows that |C|=N𝐶𝑁|C|=N, i.e., C𝐶C is a Hamiltonian cycle. Since C𝐶C is a circuit containing only arcs from 𝒟𝒟\mathcal{D}, it follows that 𝒟𝒟\mathcal{D} has a Hamiltonian cycle.

So we have proved that 𝒟𝒟\mathcal{D} has a Hamiltonian cycle if and only if 𝒢csubscript𝒢𝑐\mathcal{G}_{c} has strong spanning subdigraph of cycle time at most τ0=N+2Nsubscript𝜏0𝑁2𝑁\tau_{0}=\frac{N+2}{N}. It follows that Mct-Decision is NP-complete, thus Mct is NP-hard even when 𝒢csubscript𝒢𝑐\mathcal{G}_{c} is a complete Euclidean edge-capacitated graph. ∎

E.3 Proof of Proposition 3.3

Under the assumption that the connectivity topology is Euclidean (delays are symmetric and verify triangular inequality), we first show that the solution of Travelling Salesman Problem (Tsp) [33] is guaranteed to be within a 2​N2𝑁2N-multiplicative factor of the solution of Mct (Lemma E.3). As a result, the Christofides algorithm [73] which is a 1.5-approximation algorithm for Tsp, is a 3​N3𝑁3N-approximation algorithm for Mct (Prop. 3.3).

Lemma E.3.

Consider an Euclidean digraph 𝒢csubscript𝒢𝑐\mathcal{G}_{c} with N𝑁N nodes and let ℋ∗superscriptℋ\mathcal{H}^{*} denote its optimal tour. Then dc​(ℋ∗)|ℋ∗|≤2​N×τ∗subscript𝑑𝑐superscriptℋsuperscriptℋ2𝑁subscript𝜏\frac{d_{c}(\mathcal{H}^{*})}{|\mathcal{H}^{*}|}\leq 2N\times\tau_{*}, where τ∗subscript𝜏\tau_{*} is the optimal cycle time that can be achieved by a strong spanning subdigraph of 𝒢csubscript𝒢𝑐\mathcal{G}_{c}.

Proof.

Let 𝒢∗superscript𝒢\mathcal{G}^{*} be a spanning digraph of 𝒢csubscript𝒢𝑐\mathcal{G}_{c} with optimal cycle time τ∗superscript𝜏\tau^{*}.

Let {𝒞i}i=1,…,csubscriptsubscript𝒞𝑖𝑖1…𝑐\left\{\mathcal{C}_{i}\right\}_{i=1,\dots,c} be a minimal set of elementary circuits of 𝒢∗subscript𝒢\mathcal{G}_{*}, so that ∪i=1c𝒞i=𝒢∗superscriptsubscript𝑖1𝑐subscript𝒞𝑖subscript𝒢\cup_{i=1}^{c}\mathcal{C}_{i}=\mathcal{G}_{*} and ∪i≠j𝒞i≠𝒢∗subscript𝑖𝑗subscript𝒞𝑖subscript𝒢\cup_{i\neq j}\mathcal{C}_{i}\neq\mathcal{G}_{*} for each j𝑗j (as illustrated in Fig. 6(a)). Consider an auxiliary graph 𝒢′superscript𝒢′\mathcal{G}^{\prime} whose c𝑐c nodes represent the c𝑐c circuits and whose links correspond to two circuits sharing a node. Let 𝒯𝒯\mathcal{T} be a spanning tree of 𝒢′superscript𝒢′\mathcal{G}^{\prime}. Starting from the root of 𝒯𝒯\mathcal{T}, we can define an order of the nodes in each circuit and an order of the children of each circuit as follows. Given the orientation of the circuit corresponding to the root, consider the first node they share with each child. We order the children according to such order (solving arbitrarily possible ties). For each child we reorder its nodes starting from the node they share with the father and following the orientation of the circuit. We consider then the ordered traversal of the circuits Γ=(𝒞i1,𝒞i2,…,𝒞i2​c+1=𝒞i1)Γsubscript𝒞subscript𝑖1subscript𝒞subscript𝑖2…subscript𝒞subscript𝑖2𝑐1subscript𝒞subscript𝑖1\Gamma=(\mathcal{C}_{i_{1}},\mathcal{C}_{i_{2}},\dots,\mathcal{C}_{i_{2c+1}}=\mathcal{C}_{i_{1}}) obtained using DFS on 𝒯𝒯\mathcal{T} and visiting the children according to the order introduced above (as illustrated in Fig. 6(b)).

From ΓΓ\Gamma we can build two closed walks 𝒲1subscript𝒲1\mathcal{W}_{1} and 𝒲2subscript𝒲2\mathcal{W}_{2}, both spanning all nodes of 𝒢∗superscript𝒢\mathcal{G}^{*}. The walk 𝒲1subscript𝒲1\mathcal{W}_{1} is built by considering all circuits in the order they appear in ΓΓ\Gamma, and then concatenating their nodes as follows. The first time we visit one circuit we take all nodes in the circuit in their order (but the last one in each circuit that coincides with the first one). When we come back to the circuit, we only pick the nodes needed to move to the following circuit in ΓΓ\Gamma. The walk 𝒲2subscript𝒲2\mathcal{W}_{2} is built by considering the c𝑐c circuits in the order they first appear in ΓΓ\Gamma, and then again concatenating their nodes (but the last one in each circuit that coincides with the first one). Both sequences of nodes define walks as 𝒢csubscript𝒢𝑐\mathcal{G}_{c} is Euclidean and then complete. The length of 𝒲2subscript𝒲2\mathcal{W}_{2} is |𝒲2|=∑i=1c|𝒞i|≤N2subscript𝒲2superscriptsubscript𝑖1𝑐subscript𝒞𝑖superscript𝑁2|\mathcal{W}_{2}|=\sum_{i=1}^{c}|\mathcal{C}_{i}|\leq N^{2}, as we can have at most N−1𝑁1N-1 elementary circuits and each of them has length at most N𝑁N. See Figs. 6(c) and 6(d) for the examples of 𝒲1subscript𝒲1\mathcal{W}_{1} and 𝒲2subscript𝒲2\mathcal{W}_{2}.

We observe that dc​(𝒲1)≤2​∑i=1cdc​(𝒞i)subscript𝑑𝑐subscript𝒲12superscriptsubscript𝑖1𝑐subscript𝑑𝑐subscript𝒞𝑖d_{c}(\mathcal{W}_{1})\leq 2\sum_{i=1}^{c}d_{c}(\mathcal{C}_{i}) as the walk 𝒲1subscript𝒲1\mathcal{W}_{1} passes through each link in each circuit 𝒞isubscript𝒞𝑖\mathcal{C}_{i} at most twice: it walks through the first |𝒞i|−1subscript𝒞𝑖1|\mathcal{C}_{i}|-1 edges of 𝒞isubscript𝒞𝑖\mathcal{C}_{i} the first time it visits 𝒞isubscript𝒞𝑖\mathcal{C}_{i}, and uses once more the edges in 𝒞isubscript𝒞𝑖\mathcal{C}_{i} to visit the other circuits and go back to the root. As 𝒲2subscript𝒲2\mathcal{W}_{2} is a sublist of the nodes in 𝒲1subscript𝒲1\mathcal{W}_{1} and delays satisfy the triangle inequality, it holds dc​(𝒲2)≤dc​(𝒲1)subscript𝑑𝑐subscript𝒲2subscript𝑑𝑐subscript𝒲1d_{c}(\mathcal{W}_{2})\leq d_{c}(\mathcal{W}_{1}).

Proposition 3.3.

Christofides’ algorithm [73] is a 3​N3𝑁3N-approximation algorithm for Mct when 𝒢csubscript𝒢𝑐\mathcal{G}_{c} is edge-capacitated and Euclidean.

Proof.

Christofides algorithm provides a 3232\frac{3}{2}-approximation for the traveling salesman problem Tsp defined in [4].111111See [73] for the proof. Given an instance of Mct let C^^𝐶\hat{C} denote the output of Christofides algorithm and C∗superscript𝐶C^{*} denote the optimal tour of 𝒢csubscript𝒢𝑐\mathcal{G}_{c}. It follows that dc​(C^)≤32​dc​(C∗)subscript𝑑𝑐^𝐶32subscript𝑑𝑐superscript𝐶d_{c}(\hat{C})\leq\frac{3}{2}d_{c}(C^{*}). Since both C^^𝐶\hat{C} and C∗superscript𝐶C^{*} are Hamiltonian cycles, |C^|=|C∗|^𝐶superscript𝐶|\hat{C}|=|C^{*}|. Using Lemma E.3. it follows that dc​(C^)|C^|≤2​N×32×τ∗=3​N×τ∗subscript𝑑𝑐^𝐶^𝐶2𝑁32subscript𝜏3𝑁subscript𝜏\frac{d_{c}(\hat{C})}{|\hat{C}|}\leq 2N\times\frac{3}{2}\times\tau_{*}=3N\times\tau_{*}. Thus the graph obtained using only the edges of C^^𝐶\hat{C} is a 3​N3𝑁3N-approximation of the Mct problem when 𝒢csubscript𝒢𝑐\mathcal{G}_{c} is edge-capacitated and Euclidean. ∎

Observation E.4.

Christofides’ algorithm [73] is a Ω​(N)Ω𝑁\Omega(N)-approximation algorithm for Mct when 𝒢csubscript𝒢𝑐\mathcal{G}_{c} is edge-capacitated and Euclidean.

Proof.

Christofides’ algorithm returns a ring as solution. We provide an example of an Euclidean underlay where any ring has cycle time at least N/4𝑁4N/4 times larger than the optimal overlay. We consider a complete connectivity graph 𝒢c=(𝒱,𝒱×𝒱)subscript𝒢𝑐𝒱𝒱𝒱\mathcal{G}_{c}=\left(\mathcal{V},\mathcal{V}\times\mathcal{V}\right) to which we associate a delay function dcsubscript𝑑𝑐d_{c} verifying

∀(i,j)∈𝒱×𝒱;dc(i,j)={0if​i,j∈{1,…,N},1if​i∈{N+1,…,2​N}​or​j∈{N+1,…,2​N}.\forall(i,j)\in\mathcal{V}\times\mathcal{V};~{}~{}d_{c}(i,j)=\left\{\begin{matrix}[l]0&\text{if}~{}~{}i,j\in\{1,\dots,N\},\\ 1&\text{if}~{}~{}i\in\{N+1,\dots,2N\}~{}~{}\text{or}~{}~{}j\in\{N+1,\dots,2N\}.\end{matrix}\right. (16)

𝒢csubscript𝒢𝑐\mathcal{G}_{c} is clearly an Euclidean graph.

A Hamiltonian cycle ℋℋ\mathcal{H} of 𝒢csubscript𝒢𝑐\mathcal{G}_{c} needs to use exactly 2​N2𝑁2N different edges and in particular N𝑁N different edges with delay 111 to connect nodes i∈{N+1,…,2​N}𝑖𝑁1…2𝑁i\in\{N+1,\ldots,2N\}. Therefore, the total delay of the cycle is at least N×0+N×1=N𝑁0𝑁1𝑁N\times 0+N\times 1=N, and its cycle time τ​(ℋ)≥N2​N=12𝜏ℋ𝑁2𝑁12\tau(\mathcal{H})\geq\frac{N}{2N}=\frac{1}{2}.

Consider a directed overlay 𝒢o=(𝒱,ℰo)subscript𝒢𝑜𝒱subscriptℰ𝑜\mathcal{G}_{o}=\left(\mathcal{V},\mathcal{E}_{o}\right), with

ℰo={(i,i+1);i∈{1,…,N−1}}∪⋃K∈{N+1,…,2​N}​{(N,K),(K,1)}.subscriptℰ𝑜𝑖𝑖1𝑖1…𝑁1𝐾𝑁1…2𝑁𝑁𝐾𝐾1\mathcal{E}_{o}=\left\{(i,i+1);~{}i\in\{1,\dots,N-1\}\right\}\cup\underset{K\in\{N+1,\dots,2N\}}{\bigcup}\left\{(N,K),(K,1)\right\}. (17)

The set of elementary circuits of ℰosubscriptℰ𝑜\mathcal{E}_{o} is exactly the set

𝒞={CK=(1,…,N,K,1):K∈{N+1,2​N}}.𝒞conditional-setsubscript𝐶𝐾1…𝑁𝐾1𝐾𝑁12𝑁\mathcal{C}=\left\{C_{K}=(1,\dots,N,K,1):K\in\{N+1,2N\}\right\}.

For any circuit CK∈𝒞subscript𝐶𝐾𝒞C_{K}\in\mathcal{C},

τ​(CK)=0×(N−1)+2×1N+1=2N+1.𝜏subscript𝐶𝐾0𝑁121𝑁12𝑁1\tau(C_{K})=\frac{0\times(N-1)+2\times 1}{N+1}=\frac{2}{N+1}.

It follows that the minimal cycle time τOPT=2N+1subscript𝜏OPT2𝑁1\tau_{\text{OPT}}=\frac{2}{N+1}, and τ​(ℋ)≥N+14​τOPT𝜏ℋ𝑁14subscript𝜏OPT\tau(\mathcal{H})\geq\frac{N+1}{4}\tau_{\text{OPT}} for any Hamiltonian cycle ℋℋ\mathcal{H} of 𝒢csubscript𝒢𝑐\mathcal{G}_{c}. ∎

E.4 Proof of Proposition 3.4

We prove that in a node-capacitated network, Mct is NP-hard even when 𝒢osubscript𝒢𝑜\mathcal{G}_{o} is required to be undirected. We start introducing the associated decision problem: {problem} Mct-U-Decision is closely related to the degree-constrained spanning tree (Dcst) defined below: {problem} Dcst is a simpler version of δ𝛿\delta-Mbst, where we look for a spanning tree with degree at most k𝑘k and minimum bottleneck.

Dcst is NP-complete [27]. For example for k=2𝑘2k=2 it can be shown by a reduction from Hc.

Proposition 3.4.

In node-capacitated networks Mct is NP-hard even when the overlay is required to be undirected.

Proof.

Our proof is based on a reduction of Dcst to Mct-U-Decision.

Given an instance of Dcst with an N𝑁N-node connected undirected graph 𝒢=(𝒱,ℰ)𝒢𝒱ℰ\mathcal{G}=(\mathcal{V},\mathcal{E}) and a positive integer k≤N𝑘𝑁k\leq N, we define an instance of Mct-U-Decision on a connected graph 𝒢c=(𝒱c,ℰc)subscript𝒢𝑐subscript𝒱𝑐subscriptℰ𝑐\mathcal{G}_{c}=(\mathcal{V}_{c},\mathcal{E}_{c}) built from 𝒢𝒢\mathcal{G} according to the following mapping ΠΠ\Pi: For each node v𝑣v in 𝒱𝒱\mathcal{V}, there are two nodes v(1)superscript𝑣1v^{(1)} and v(2)superscript𝑣2v^{(2)} in 𝒱csubscript𝒱𝑐\mathcal{V}_{c} and (v(1),v(2))∈ℰcsuperscript𝑣1superscript𝑣2subscriptℰ𝑐(v^{(1)},v^{(2)})\in\mathcal{E}_{c}, and for an arc (vi,vj)∈ℰsubscript𝑣𝑖subscript𝑣𝑗ℰ(v_{i},v_{j})\in\mathcal{E}, there is an arc (vi(1),vj(1))superscriptsubscript𝑣𝑖1superscriptsubscript𝑣𝑗1(v_{i}^{(1)},v_{j}^{(1)}) in ℰcsubscriptℰ𝑐\mathcal{E}_{c}. Suppose that 𝒢𝒢\mathcal{G} has a spanning tree 𝒯=(𝒱,ℰ𝒯)𝒯𝒱subscriptℰ𝒯\mathcal{T}=(\mathcal{V},\mathcal{E}_{\mathcal{T}}) in which no node has degree greater than k𝑘k, and denote 𝒯c=Π​(𝒯)subscript𝒯𝑐Π𝒯\mathcal{T}_{c}=\Pi(\mathcal{T}) (i.e., we apply the same mapping described above). Then the answer to Dcst is positive if and only if the answer to Mct-U-Decision is positive. In addition, we have a polynomial reduction algorithm. It follows that Mct-U-Decision is NP-hard. ∎

Lemma E.5 establishes a connection between the bottleneck of the Mbst of 𝒢c(u)subscriptsuperscript𝒢𝑢𝑐\mathcal{G}^{(u)}_{c} and the cycle time of Mct on 𝒢csubscript𝒢𝑐\mathcal{G}_{c} when the overlay is required to be undirected. To get an approximated 222-Mbst on 𝒢c(u)subscriptsuperscript𝒢𝑢𝑐\mathcal{G}^{(u)}_{c}, we apply the best known 333-approximation algorithm from [3, Sect. 3.2.1] (see lines 1-1 in Algo. 1) which requires 𝒢c(u)subscriptsuperscript𝒢𝑢𝑐\mathcal{G}^{(u)}_{c} to be Euclidean. So in the following, we show that indeed 𝒢c(u)subscriptsuperscript𝒢𝑢𝑐\mathcal{G}^{(u)}_{c} is Euclidean.

Proposition 3.5.

Algorithm 1 is a 666-approximation algorithm for Mct when 𝒢csubscript𝒢𝑐\mathcal{G}_{c} is node-capacitated and Euclidean with CUP​(i)≤min⁡(CDN​(j)N,A​(i′,j′))subscript𝐶UP𝑖subscript𝐶DN𝑗𝑁𝐴superscript𝑖′superscript𝑗′C_{\textrm{UP}}(i)\leq\min\left(\frac{C_{\textrm{DN}}(j)}{N},A(i^{\prime},j^{\prime})\right), ∀(i,j)∈ℰcfor-all𝑖𝑗subscriptℰ𝑐\forall(i,j)\in\mathcal{E}_{c}, and 𝒢osubscript𝒢𝑜\mathcal{G}_{o} is required to be undirected.

Proof.

Algorithm 1 considers, as a candidate solution, an opportune Hamiltonian path ℋℋ\mathcal{H} (line 1) for which reference [3, Thm. 8] proves that

as 𝒢c(u)subscriptsuperscript𝒢𝑢𝑐\mathcal{G}^{(u)}_{c} is Euclidean (Lemma E.6). Moreover,
